1. Who out of the now 7 Democratic candidates do you think is best fit all around to be the president of the United States and why?
 
 2. Which Democrats do you think could beat Bush?
 
 3. Who do you predict to win the Democratic election?
 
 ----------------------------
 
 My response:
 
 1. I supported Joe Lieberman, but due to his lack of support I'm closely watching Kerry and Edwards.
 
 2. If Dean were to be elected I think he would be slaughtered by George Bush for several reasons. But we can get into that later.
 I think Edwards has a good chance of beating Bush and that Kerry would give him a tight race. 
 
 3. I'm predicting John Edwards. Besides of actual logic that I have behind this prediction, I had a dream sometime before Christmas (when Dean was at front-runner status) that Edwards won the election.

1. Joe Lieberman for sure. If he keeps where he is and maintains his beliefs instead of pandering he would be best suited. He has experience, he hasn't shifted his opinions, etc.
 
 2. Joe Lieberman or John Edwards. They have the ability to get the independents.
 
 3. I now think it'll be Kerry or possibly even Edwards.
 
 After Howard Dean's speech last night, I was seriously scared. That has to of been one of the worst speeches by any politican that I have ever heard... he sounded like he had enjoyed a bottle of energy pills before he ran out there and ate an anger bar with it. :-\ After that and all his other antics on the trail I no longer think he will be the one to win the nomination.

Broker,
 
 

 After Howard Dean's speech last night, I was seriously scared. That has to of been one of the worst speeches by any politican that I have ever heard... he sounded like he had enjoyed a bottle of energy pills before he ran out there and ate an anger bar with it. :-\ After that and all his other antics on the trail I no longer think he will be the one to win the nomination.

 
 No I seriously doubt that Howard Dean will win. As has been commented the speech would make a perfect ad for Bush or any Democratic Candidates.

1. Liberman. He really seems to be almost independent in how he makes his decisions which in my mind makes him the most level headed person in the democratic field.
 
 2. I really don't think any of them could beat Bush right now. Bush has the economy going for him and is the only person on the list that is really taking terrorism seriously. He has too much going for him and I think he wins the next election regardless of who goes against him. Liberman and Edwards would probably provide the most competition to him though since they are moderate democrats.
 
 3. Kerry will probably win the democratic election. Edwards started out behind Kerry and I don't think he has enough time to catch up. Dean already cut his own throat so it is all but over for him.

AMD,
 
 
Liberman. He really seems to be almost independent in how he makes his decisions which in my mind makes him the most level headed person in the democratic field.

 
 I wish the polls reflected this.
 
 
Liberman and Edwards would probably provide the most competition to him though since they are moderate democrats.

 
 According to the leader of Australia, Bush told him that the candidate he feared the most was Lieberman.
 
 What about Kerry? 
 
 
Edwards started out behind Kerry and I don't think he has enough time to catch up.

 
 I disagree. We all saw what a few days could do to an election. Edwards is being payed more attention to due to his victory in Iowa. I think that while it doesn't seem like he is going to win New Hampshire, he has a great oppurunity to win South Carolina.
 Edwards chances will greatly depend on:
 Any endorsements. (SC senator) (which will mean money)
 The on coming debate on Thursday as well as any future debates.
 
 If Dean finishes 3rd or worse in NH, I think he can be counted as crashing and burning.
 
 
Dean already cut his own throat so it is all but over for him.

 
 Dean did more poorly than expected in Iowa and had already suffered a loss but when he had a chance to attempt to pull it around he absolutely blew it and made a bad situation worse.

The Democrats are making a huge mistake... the only person who can beat Bush is Lieberman. Why? Because he already did. 
 
 He's a moderate, stong on defense, values, taxes, etc. He's more of a Conservative Democrat... if the Democrats really wanted to retake power they would be behind him.
 
 
 If Dean were to win I think we'd be watching Dean go "argghhhh" in campaign ads over and over again... what a stupid speech... I can't wait to get SNL's take on that one...

The Democrats are making a huge mistake... the only person who can beat Bush is Lieberman. Why? Because he already did. 
 
 He's a moderate, stong on defense, values, taxes, etc. He's more of a Conservative Democrat... if the Democrats really wanted to retake power they would be behind him.

 
 I do agree with you.
 
 I thinK Lieberman would make an excellent president and that he could beat Geogre W. Bush.
 
 I wish Democrats could see that.
 
 
If Dean were to win I think we'd be watching Dean go "argghhhh" in campaign ads over and over again... what a stupid speech... I can't wait to get SNL's take on that one...

 
 Have you seen the one where his head blows off?
 
 Dealing with the ongoing (as of now) Democratic Debate I would like to voice my protest to the Fox News channel's hosting:
 
 For 5 straight questions in a row he was asked 1 - 2 follow-up questions by the moderators (who are supposed to be unbiased) in an attempt to find inconsistincies with his statements or views.
 As of now I have only seen 1 follow up question to 1 other candidate.

He's certainly the only one I would consider supporting...
 
 
 I didn't notice anything unusual in any of the questioning. Howard Dean's greatest problem is that he's Howard Dean. His worst enemy is his mouth... he's got the most to scrutinize.

He's certainly the only one I would consider supporting...

 
 Why not Kerry or Edwards?
 
 
I didn't notice anything unusual in any of the questioning. 
 
 
 I most certainly did.
 
 
Howard Dean's greatest problem is that he's Howard Dean. His worst enemy is his mouth... he's got the most to scrutinize.

 
 There doesn't need to be any negative proclomations against Dean. He hurts himself more than any candidates possibly could.

I only caught the last half hour of debating but in that last half hour the best statements were made by Kerry, Edwards, and Liberman. No one else had anything good to say. Kerry really does surprise me with how good he is at speaking in a forum like this. I think that if he goes head to head with GWB in a debate he is going to tear him up. Kerry has a good chance of winning simply because he can go well over top the head of Bush in any verbal activity. I'm starting to believe Bush doesn't have this election locked up by any means.

If Dean or Kerry could fit the label of Conservative I would gladly consider supporting them against Bush too, but I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon. 
 
 Maybe it's just the fact that no one else has said much that needs questioning. Dean just goes off... no one else does that. You have Iowa, I think with my heart, not my head, etc, etc, etc.

AMD,
 
 
I only caught the last half hour of debating but in that last half hour the best statements were made by Kerry, Edwards, and Liberman.

 
 Lieberman did especially well in that debate.
 
 
I'm starting to believe Bush doesn't have this election locked up by any means.

 
 Don't forget his financial resources.
 
 Broker,
 
 
If Dean or Kerry could fit the label of Conservative I would gladly consider supporting them against Bush too, but I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon. 
 
 
 Among other reasons I am not supporting Dean because of his anti-war position.
I didn't mean Dean, I meant Edwards... sorry. But I wouldn't support any of them for their flip flop anyway.

Kerry is now doing very well, after winning both Iowa and New Hampshire.
 
 Dean seems to be facing many problems including a financial one. With that he has seemed to concede the upcoming primaries / caucuses as he as pulled all tv advertising in those states.
 
 Edwards is being followed closely behind Kerry in a recent SC poll and it seems his campaign may quickly die if he does not win SC.
 
 Clark is being led by Kerry in all states exempting Oklahoma (if I remember correctly).
 
 The rest seem to have no chance.
 
 Does anyone have a chance to beat Kerry for the Democratic nomination? 
 If so... who and how?

Lieberman is close to taking first in some poll. Clark is ahead in one, Edwards another... Kerry most of the rest. But if any of these guys wins a state they could easily gain some huge momentum...
 
 Fact is often the winners of Iowa and New Hampshire don't get the nomination...

Lieberman is close to taking first in some poll.

 
 What state is that?
 
 
Fact is often the winners of Iowa and New Hampshire don't get the nomination...

 
 The winners of both Iowa and New Hampshire? Maybe I'm wrong but I thought I rememberd hearing that history shows that anyone who wins both Iowa and New Hampshire whether Democrat or Republican goes on to win the nomination.
 
 
 
But if any of these guys wins a state they could easily gain some huge momentum...

 
 
 I think that after these primaries the race will primarily become a two man race despite what Dean tries to do later on.

What state is that?
 
 The winners of both Iowa and New Hampshire? Maybe I'm wrong but I thought I rememberd hearing that history shows that anyone who wins both Iowa and New Hampshire whether Democrat or Republican goes on to win the nomination.
 
 
 I think that after these primaries the race will primarily become a two man race despite what Dean tries to do later on.

 
 
 I think that it is almost assured at this point that Kerry is going to be the nominee, but the question about if he can beat Bush is still debatable. Of course, at this point it seems as though he can, he beat Bush by a lot in the last head to head poll that i saw (CNN). Of course all of the exposure of the primaries has helped him a lot, and his numbers will probably go down, but it does seem that he is certainly competitive.
 One thing that was mentioned that I am curious about is that some people on this thread said that Lieberman had a good chance because he was 'strong on defense'. You hear this a lot about differnent candidates, and I was wondering what that actaully means to people...to be 'strong on defense.'

I think that it is almost assured at this point that Kerry is going to be the nominee, but the question about if he can beat Bush is still debatable. Of course, at this point it seems as though he can, he beat Bush by a lot in the last head to head poll that i saw (CNN). Of course all of the exposure of the primaries has helped him a lot, and his numbers will probably go down, but it does seem that he is certainly competitive.

 
 I don't hold those polls to be of any value. Once the nominee is chosen there will be months of campaigning and debate. The numbers will go up and down.
 
 
One thing that was mentioned that I am curious about is that some people on this thread said that Lieberman had a good chance because he was 'strong on defense'. You hear this a lot about differnent candidates, and I was wondering what that actaully means to people...to be 'strong on defense.'

 
 I think Lieberman had one of the best chances at beating Bush. He's intelligent and consistent.

Those polls are flawed. That always happens... happened with Reagan and with Clinton. With Reagan the guy went on to lose all but one state... Clinton beat Dole in a landslide. So those polls mean nothing right now.
 
 Remember, Bush isn't campaigning yet...

I think Kerry's quite formidable and a good opponent for Bush. He served in Vietnam and is held in prestige in the war community. He's gotten many medals and I think he's charismatic, educated and well-rounded. I think he's got a good chance at ejecting Bush from power, regardless of what anyone else says. November will bestow the answer upon us, and I think it's improbable Bush wins this time around. I'm not concerned about Bush's purported economical aptitude, I doubt it'll save him. Anyways, we keep the embargoes and exporting way down and the economy will continue to grow.
With a Kerry vs. Bush match is very conceivable that Kerry could pull off a victory.

I don't hold those polls to be of any value. Once the nominee is chosen there will be months of campaigning and debate. The numbers will go up and down.
 
 I think Lieberman had one of the best chances at beating Bush. He's intelligent and consistent.

 
 
 Yes, I agree for sure that the numbers will go up and down, I just meant that it definetly seems possible at this point given that Kerry certainly seems competitive.
 
 I am not sure if I feel that Liebermant could have beat Bush...at any rate, I don't think that he ever had a chance to win the primary because he is just way too conservative. I don't think that he would have won Connecticut.

I think Kerry's quite formidable and a good opponent for Bush. He served in Vietnam and is held in prestige in the war community. He's gotten many medals and I think he's charismatic, educated and well-rounded. I think he's got a good chance at ejecting Bush from power, regardless of what anyone else says. November will bestow the answer upon us, and I think it's improbable Bush wins this time around. I'm not concerned about Bush's purported economical aptitude, I doubt it'll save him. Anyways, we keep the embargoes and exporting way down and the economy will continue to grow.

 
 
 Yeah, I think that most people feel pretty good about Kerry. The only thing that I see really hurting him is the historic thing, being both a senator and from Massachusettes. I think that the was hero thing is going to really help him...it seems that the Democrats really need someone with a war record, because the Republicans still seem that they are able to convince people that they are more patriotic. That will be hard with Kerry vs Bush.
 It also seems that in many primaries, there has been very good turnout. Perhaps (from a Democrats perspective) the only thing good about Bush is that he may have really galvanized Democrats to come out and vote.

There hasn't been a president from a Northern state in... how many years? Almost 30? I don't think Kerry can change that trend. He's taken the most special interest money of everyone in the Senate... he's got a liberal voting record that reads like Ted Kennedy's.
 
 His voting record will hurt him on security. Kerry voted against the Patriot, Trident, F-15, F-16, B-2, and countless other defense projects that have shaped our military. Most people don't know this. When they find out it will be very difficult for Kerry to find trust among people in security...

There hasn't been a president from a Northern state in... how many years? Almost 30? I don't think Kerry can change that trend. He's taken the most special interest money of everyone in the Senate... he's got a liberal voting record that reads like Ted Kennedy's.
 

 
 
 That, of course is the fear...(a senator from New England) I believe that Kennedy was both the last president from New England and the last senator to be elected. The theory being, of course, that a candidate from the south could pick up some southern states. THere is, however, a school of thought (growing I believe) that the south really doesn't matter, anyway. If Gore would have won New Hampshire, he would have won without winning a single southern state.
 
 http://www.uselectionatlas.org/USPRESIDENT/
 
 

 His voting record will hurt him on security. Kerry voted against the Patriot, Trident, F-15, F-16, B-2, and countless other defense projects that have shaped our military. Most people don't know this. When they find out it will be very difficult for Kerry to find trust among people in security...

 
 That is, of course, why it is tough to win as a senator, because eveyone who has been in the senate for a long time has a voting record that can be criticized. I still think that we will hold up to defense criticism, though...it may be tough for Republicans to convince people that a war hero is 'weak on defense' and an unpatriotic. Then again, they were able to do it with Max Cleland, I never would have dreamed that was possible...

Gore was still a Southerner...

 
 
 Yeah, kind of (depeding on what you consider the south). I am not saying that southerners always win for the dems (Carter lost in 1980), only that when they have nominated northerners recently, they have lost (Humphrey, McGovern, Mondale, Dukakis) thus the fear of some to nominate a northerner like Kerry.

Kerry's going to smash Bush, I think. He's got his war records to recompense for his turning down such an effective, efficient "Patriot Act" and other things.
 Well, it'll be a nail-biter, but when I say "smash" his possible triumph seems more emphatic.
 
 I think many of the Conservative Christians will hold Bush accountable for the recent surge in legality of gay marriages and I also think many are angry about the administration's erroneous intelligence and faulty rationale. Then there's the 9/11 Panel and the deficit. Bush has many, many, many cons. The only way I see him being re-elected is if he digs up Osama bin Laden, which I don't find to be that unlikely. Osama's maimed carcass will emerge on front-page photographs two days before the scheduled election and Bush will be immortalized and loved by all the populace of America.
 
 The list goes on and on... since Kerry's never held presidency it's hard to dig up really damaging dirt on him, other than his seat in the senate, even that won't disintegrate his good image, I think.
 
 If Americans were aware of how demonized our country has become under George W. Bush's term as far as a global aspect is concerned I wonder if they'd still vote Bush. Yeah, probably, there are a lot of radicals out there that won't opine anything other than, "Bush is great, I think. He's good regardless of how badly he corrodes the image of America."

Kerry voted against the Defense of Marriage Act... Clinton legislation. Bush is probably going to call for a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage... I don't see Conservative Christians jumping over to Kerry. :-\
 
 I don't think Kerry can win. Once Bush and Kerry go at it the polls will shift... Kerry's going to call Bush the big friend of special interests and Bush is going to blow it up right in his face. Kerry's going to probably try to claim that Bush went AWOL and that's going to also blow up in his face...

Kerry voted against the Defense of Marriage Act... Clinton legislation. Bush is probably going to call for a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage... I don't see Conservative Christians jumping over to Kerry. :-\

 Actually, I read in an article in my local newspaper that many Conservative Christians were dismayed with Bush's lack of intervention in the whole gay marriage issue. Also, I don't know if you're living in a cardboard box or whether you're a denizen of Bushworld, but Bush's popularity is declining and even my diehard Conservative parents are doubting his utmost priorities lie within the appropriate area. Many of the alterations sustained by America have been due to Bush's religious ambition and his intention to appeal to the conservative christians. Even with the inclusion of these things you've got to keep other issues in mind that are vital to all walks of life.
 
 Though you're right, Bush seems to favor a less secular and more religious governmental infrastructure, so he'll probably attempt to abolish gay marriage. Even if he does manage to extract votes from certain demographs, I still don't think he'll prevail. Rest assured, Bush will likely lose. His cons outweigh his pros, and can't be disacknowledged by anything else. 
 
 
I don't think Kerry can win. Once Bush and Kerry go at it the polls will shift... Kerry's going to call Bush the big friend of special interests and Bush is going to blow it up right in his face. Kerry's going to probably try to claim that Bush went AWOL and that's going to also blow up in his face...

 
 Fact: Bush did go AWOL in the U.S. Air National Guard; that buffoon also failed the mandatory tests to become a pilot because of his haphazard attitude. I read in my local paper he was gone for quite some time. This is not a fallacy and I'm sure records - undoctored to the interests of biased conservatives- would vouch for it. 
 
 Kerry's smarter, more charismatic, can string together intelligible sentences without faltering and would likely cater to the interests of everyone. I know it's difficult to conceive Bush may lose in the next election so you try to come to his aid. Naturally, you've adopted conservative ideals and such and will do your damnedest to defend him. November will tell the truth, however. I'm sure it could swing either way but I think Kerry has more presidential aptitude and savvy.

According to the New York Times and Washington Post, both who conducted extensive investigations on the subject, that's simply not true... Bush's flight commander says that Bush was one of the top five pilots he had.
 
 In the end people vote with their wallets... and the economy is only getting better.

According to the New York Times and Washington Post, both who conducted extensive investigations on the subject, that's simply not true... Bush's flight commander says that Bush was one of the top five pilots he had.

 Please, like I give a XXXX? Of course he's willing to bend the truth a bit; no-one's willing to intentionally and consciously desecrate the president's image.
 When I see an unbiased article that concisely asserts Bush failed his exam and also missed most of the duties he was obligated to attend based on records and colleague reports, I'm going to believe it. And that's what I read and believed. I usually draw my facts from unbiased reports, regardless of whether they be conservative, liberal or radical. If there's an irrefuted fact I'm going to absorb it. 
 The grades don't lie, the media does.
 
 
In the end people vote with their wallets... and the economy is only getting better.

 
 Notice how the GDP didn't grow as much when we slightly increased the imports? Yeah, exactly. Also, many people don't attribute financial success directly to the president and many don't think the economy is always the working of ol' pres'. There's no reason to believe this will deter potential democratic voters, they've done well handling the economy the past few terms they've been in office and people are also concerned about the deficit and the honesty of the president. I'm also aware of your delusional beliefs that the economy prospered under Clinton because of the leash the republicans in congress held on him, but that's baseless, biased malarkey.
 I guarantee our economy will start lagging once PCE goes down and imports go up and embargos are lifted. It won't be bad, but this phenomenal spurt won't be perpetual, either.

First of all, you're talking two years out of seven that are in question. He didn't fail the exam either. He passed it, but you're right, barely.
 
 The president has almost no real control over the economy... no president has. But the public always assign its status to the president...

First of all, you're talking two years out of seven that are in question. He didn't fail the exam either. He passed it, but you're right, barely.

 
 According to an article I read in the AP he did fail his exam, dismally so. Perhaps he passed it later or after a few re-tries, but he failed terribly and was often described as inattentive and apathetic to his obligatory duties. Of course, it's difficult to draw any line between the juvenile-minded Bush of the past and the... uh... adult-minded Bush of the present?
 
 
The president has almost no real control over the economy... no president has. But the public always assign its status to the president...

 
 I know I sure don't. I've learned from the past several presidencies that this can't be ascribed to how adept a man is during his reign on the throne.

That's now what I've read.... Anyway, people change. I don't think it's fair to judge people on their past... that was, like, 40 years ago.
 
 The president doesn't really have any control. That's the truth... doesn't matter what you do. It's very difficult for the president to influence the economy at all... this isn't socialist Europe...

Electibility -
 
 On the exit polls there is one vital quality, that to voters, Kerry seems to posses. They think he is electible.
 Why?
 
 ..........
 
 
 Surely the American people aren't silly enough to beleive that the newsweek polls that show Kerry ahead of Bush mean something. They don't. We still have a solid five months of debates, campaigning, and fundrasing. This gives plenty of time for major events and slip-ups.
 
 When you vote for someone in a primary, electibility is kind of a silly quality to vote on.
 
 Because its what will make them electible that counts and that you should vote for:
 
 Background
 Personality
 Views
 Intelligence
 Voting Record
 Message
 Etc...
 
 When the voters come to the general election are they going to look at the two candidates and say: "Hmmm... he looks electible"
 
 Of course not. They are going to vote on the things mentioned above.
 
 Any comments?

Kerry will get the ticket, which makes me sad, but he will also get my vote because Bush makes me sick. I somehow think Bush will win tho..... :xbanghead

Kerry will get the ticket, which makes me sad, but he will also get my vote because Bush makes me sick. I somehow think Bush will win tho..... :xbanghead

He is a pig pig pig pig pig pig. PIG.

Well, you and I are in strong disagreement on the Patriot Act (see outcomes of 2004 election thread). That is the main reason.

 Do you mean the one that would ban same-sex marriages? Why would you be opposed to that?

 Do you mean the one that would ban same-sex marriages? Why would you be opposed to that?
 
 Because no matter how you come at it it's unconstitutional. If the basis is religious, it has no business in there. We are supposed to be free from that. And even if it is not, it is discriminatory. I actually believe government should remove its big butt from marriage all together, but I definately do not support this ammendment.

.....

 
 No opinion is worthless.
 
 It's just my opinion, but if you'd use the quote commands properly, your posts would be easier to read. Just tag the reply button within the post to which you want to reply and you'll see what the commands are.
 
 If you want anything at all to show up as a quote, you just type a square opening bracket [ then the word QUOTE then a square closing bracket ]. All this goes before the actual quote.
 
 When you are done with the quote, you type a square opening bracket [ then a slash / then the word QUOTE then a square closing bracket ]

Well, I think he is a big dummy :p , but that's a matter of opinion.
